title: Radical Specialized Sirrus Carbon removes the lower half of the seat tube for extra compliance
content:
Cyclist
Radical Specialized Sirrus Carbon removes the lower half of the seat tube for extra compliance

Specialized has today launched its striking new Sirrus Carbon hybrid bike, which uniquely features a seat tube with the bottom half removed. That leaves the top part of the seat tube, the seatpost and the saddle supported by a strut from the seatstays linking them to the down tube. Dubbed the Compliance Junction by Specialized, this is claimed to increase comfort without sacrificing performance and efficiency.

The Sirrus Carbon will be offered in both a city hybrid spec, as the Sirrus 6.0 priced at £2,400 ($3,000), and a light gravel hybrid spec, the Sirrus X 5.0 priced at £1,950 ($2,250), and in six sizes from XS to XXL. 

‘Fitness geometry’ and single-ring 12-speed drivetrain

The Sirrus Carbon frame is made from Specialized’s FACT 9r carbon fibre, and uses the brand’s Fitness Geometry to support a typical hybrid bike riding position that is shorter and more upright than a typical road bike.

Alongside the compliance at the rear from the frame design, Specialized has incorporated its Future Shock 1.5 damping system under the stem, so the bike should provide significant shock absorption at both the bars and the saddle.

Although the design is likely to have meant that the remaining frame tubes needed to be beefed up to maintain rigidity, Specialized claims that the Sirrus 6.0 weighs 9.2kg (20.3lb) and the Sirrus X 5.0 weighs 10.9kg (24lb), which is not out of line with other hybrid bikes, although the carbon frame and quality specs make the bikes more expensive than many competitors.

Without a seat tube to mount a front derailleur, both the Sirrus 6.0 and the Sirrus X 5.0 have single chainring SRAM Eagle 12-speed drivetrains, with a 40 tooth chainring in the 6.0 spec and a 38 tooth chainring for the X 5.0, paired with an 11-50 tooth cassette, providing wide range gearing. The SRAM groupsets also include hydraulic disc brakes. 

The frame provides clearance for 700c tyres up to 42mm, which is used in the Sirrus X 5.0 to fit 38mm wide Specialized Pathfinder Pro gravel bike tyres; the Sirrus 6.0 is fitted with Specialized Roubaix Pro 30/32mm tyres, for faster progress on tarmac. Both the tyres and the rims are tubeless-ready. 

The frame will allow you to fit mudguards and a rear rack, making it easy to deck out the Sirrus Carbon for commuting. Specialized hasn’t forgotten hydration needs either, with Bento Box mounts on the top tube, two sets of bottle cage mounts on the down tube and, in all but the XS and S sizes, a fourth set of mounts on the seat tube.

Will Specialized launch other new models with the Sirrus Carbon’s frame design? 

Will we see Specialized extend the use of its novel frame design to other bikes beyond the Sirrus Carbon in future? 

There was speculation when Specialized filed a patent on the frame design last year that this would be the latest iteration of the Roubaix endurance road bike. But the current generation Roubaix is frequently chosen by the athletes on Specialized’s sponsored teams for early season cobbled Classics, including the eponymous Paris-Roubaix. 

A new bike with an ostensibly less aero frame design without the option to fit a front derailleur probably wouldn’t sit very well with the pros, even if Lizzie Deignan did win the inaugural women’s Paris-Roubaix in 2021 on a single-chainring Trek Domane.

Single-ring drivetrains may not have caught on for road bikes just yet, but they’re a lot more accepted for gravel bikes. 

Specialized already has a radical compliance solution in its Diverge STR gravel bike, where the seat tube is disconnected from the rest of the frame. Here too, rather than relying on a traditional double-diamond frame design, frame integrity comes from the junction between the top tube and the seat stays.

But that bike is very expensive, at £13,000 for the S-Works spec, so there’s room in the Diverge family for a lower priced solution to provide added compliance. A drop bar gravel bike with a softer ride from a truncated seat tube could be just the ticket.
